steps.title: Check your razor.
steps.content: Check your razor. Make sure it's clean, sharp, rust-free and undamaged. If you have very light hair, you can use the same blade repeatedly. If you have coarse hair, you may only get a few shaves out of a blade. If you're not sure, once you feel the blade pulling or catching when you shave, it's time to change. [1] X Research source [2] X Expert Source Alicia Ramos Skincare Professional Expert Interview. 12 June 2019.

steps.title: Hop in the shower.
steps.content: Hop in the shower. [3] X Research source Or bath—whatever makes you more comfortable. Do your normal washing routine before you shave. You want to let your hair and skin get wet for about two to four minutes, but not so long in hot water that your follicles start to swell up, inhibiting a close shave. For extra baby soft legs exfoliate!

steps.title: Have a seat.
steps.content: Have a seat. If you're showering, have a seat on the edge of the tub. If you're in the bath, prop a foot up on the wall. You want your leg bent so that you can easily reach your ankles.

steps.title: Apply shaving cream or water-soluble skin cream.
steps.content: Apply shaving cream or water-soluble skin cream. [4] X Research source Try to find something that has moisturizers in it. The emollients help smooth the skin, and keeping it scent-free means you lower the risk of skin irritation. Using water-soluble skin cream may be kinder to your skin than traditional shaving cream; it also frees you from having to buy gender-based shaving supplies.

steps.title: Start at your ankle.
steps.content: Start at your ankle. Begin at the bottom of your leg, and with long strokes upwards, shave the hair against the grain. Don't rush; this is not a race to the finish line. It's more important to make smooth, even strokes than a speedy chop. Rinse the razor frequently—clean hot water is best—to clean and unclog the blades, and to ensure that the blades are always wet. Work your way up the leg and don't forget your inner and outer thighs. Don't forget to rinse the razor frequently. For some people, these areas don't require shaving, for some they do. Only shave hair you think is unsightly.

steps.title: Shave your feet if you want to.
steps.content: Shave your feet if you want to. Carefully repeat the process on your feet—apply the cream, shave smoothly, and rinse. Shave the tops of your toes and the top of your foot. The skin on your foot is much thinner than the skin on your legs. Use caution accordingly.

steps.title: Rinse off.
steps.content: Rinse off. [5] X Trustworthy Source American Academy of Dermatology Professional organization made of over 20,000 certified dermatologists Go to source After you've finished with one leg, rinse it off, and repeat the entire process on the other leg.

steps.title: Checked for missed spots.
steps.content: Checked for missed spots. Run the tips of your fingers over all the parts of your leg that require shaving. If you find any missed bits, shave those, then continue the inspection. When you're satisfied, all is well, rinse off, towel off, and enjoy your smooth legs.

steps.title: Moisturize.
steps.content: Moisturize. [6] X Research source Use an after-shave balm, oil, moisturizer, or medicinal embrocation to calm the skin, and reduce or eliminate the red bumps that sometimes occur with shaving. Try to exfoliate when you shave your legs, too! [7] X Expert Source Alicia Ramos Skincare Professional Expert Interview. 12 June 2019. For more tips on getting smooth legs after you shave, check out the "How do I get rid of strawberry legs fast? It's giving me the ick." forum page.

steps.title: Wash your legs.
steps.content: Wash your legs. You want your hairs moisturized and stood upright, ready to be mowed down.

steps.title: Make sure your shaver is nice and clean.
steps.content: Make sure your shaver is nice and clean. Dirty shavers will not cut as well, and could pull hairs, leaving red marks along with several "ouchies" and expletives. Always use a clean shaver. [8] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source

steps.title: Press the shaver gently against your leg.
steps.content: Press the shaver gently against your leg. [9] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Make sure all the heads touch your leg together. This will give you the closest shave with minimal wear. You don't need to apply much pressure while shaving—with just a gentle touch, let the shaver glide along your skin. If you use too much pressure, you'll flatten the hair, which results in an uneven, stubbly shave. It will also make the blades dull quicker. A gentle touch makes shaving easier and helps avoid possible skin irritation.

steps.title: Hold the razor flat against your leg.
steps.content: Hold the razor flat against your leg. Holding it at an angle could result in skin irritation and stubble.

steps.title: Grow your hair.
steps.content: Grow your hair. For waxing to work, there has to be enough hair on your legs for the wax to latch onto. [10] X Trustworthy Source American Academy of Dermatology Professional organization made of over 20,000 certified dermatologists Go to source Let your leg hair grow to at least 1/4 inch (1 cm) in length.

steps.title: Exfoliate.
steps.content: Exfoliate. [11] X Research source A couple of days before you wax your legs, use a mildly abrasive body scrub to exfoliate them. Do this ahead of time to avoid possible skin irritation problems.

steps.title: Powder your legs.
steps.content: Powder your legs. Just before you wax, sprinkle talc or baby powder on your legs. The powder will absorb any oil on your skin, and the wax sticks more easily to the hair. [12] X Trustworthy Source American Academy of Dermatology Professional organization made of over 20,000 certified dermatologists Go to source

steps.title: Warm it up.
steps.content: Warm it up. Heat the wax as directed by the manufacturer. Be sure not to overheat the wax—the resulting wax burns can be very painful.

steps.title: Pull up a comfy chair.
steps.content: Pull up a comfy chair. Have a seat on a surface that can be easily cleaned—waxing can be messy. Apply the wax carefully in a thin, uniform layer. Hold the applicator at a 90° angle, and apply the wax in the direction of hair growth. Don't forget the feet!

steps.title: Pull!
steps.content: Pull! Make the skin taut with one hand, and remove the strip with the other. Pull the strip in the opposite direction of the hair growth. [13] X Research source Pull quickly—the slower you pull, the longer the pain. Keep your hand as close to the skin as possible when you're pulling. It'll be less painful that way. Remove all the wax. Apply a damp cloth over your legs if needed, to soothe any irritation.

steps.title: Remove all the residues of wax from the surface of your skin.
steps.content: Remove all the residues of wax from the surface of your skin. Soak a cotton pad with a bit of body oil, and apply it on your legs. [14] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source

steps.title: Apply an antiseptic.
steps.content: Apply an antiseptic. After waxing, use a topical or spray-on antiseptic (containing salicylic acid) to disinfect the area, stop ingrown hairs from forming, and sooth irritation.

steps.title: Make sure your skin is clean and free of blemishes and injury.
steps.content: Make sure your skin is clean and free of blemishes and injury. [15] X Trustworthy Source American Academy of Dermatology Professional organization made of over 20,000 certified dermatologists Go to source The chemicals used will dissolve the keratin at the base of the hair shaft. Having clean skin will make this easier as oils on the skin and hair will prevent the depilatory from working effectively. Having unbroken skin will keep irritation at bay.

steps.title: Soften the hair.
steps.content: Soften the hair. Apply a warm washcloth to your legs to soften the hair. Moisten the hair for about three to five minutes. Dry your legs when done.

steps.title: Apply the cream generously, covering all the hair that you would like to remove.
steps.content: Apply the cream generously, covering all the hair that you would like to remove. Don't rub into the skin: the depilatory is designed to work without that.

steps.title: Follow the instructions.
steps.content: Follow the instructions. Leave the depilatory cream on for as long as the instructions tell you. Don't leave depilatory cream for longer than the time specified—it could irritate, or even burn your skin . [16] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Keep a timer handy so that you don't go over the limit. If your legs feel like they're burning before it's time to remove the cream, rinse it off.

steps.title: Clean up.
steps.content: Clean up. After you've finished, remove the product generally by scraping the residue with the plastic tool (if one is provided) and rinsing off whatever is left. Use a damp washcloth in a downwards motion. This will clear away any straggling hair, and finish cleaning up your legs.

steps.title: Avoid irritation.
steps.content: Avoid irritation. Try not to use harsh products or treatments after using a depilatory cream for a day or two.
